content: The Act may be cited as the "VA Expiring Authorities Extension Act of 2013" and includes a table of contents. The "VA Expiring Authorities Extension Act of 2013" includes provisions for extending various programs and authorities related to disabled veterans, adaptive sports assistance, transportation to VA facilities, nursing home care, mental health services, housing assistance for homeless veterans, and advisory committees. The "VA Expiring Authorities Extension Act of 2013" extends programs for disabled veterans, adaptive sports, transportation to VA facilities, nursing home care, mental health services, and housing assistance for homeless veterans. It also extends the authority for advisory committees and medical examinations by contract physicians under Title 38, United States Code. Budgetary effects will be determined by the latest statement for compliance with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010. The "VA Expiring Authorities Extension Act of 2013" extends programs for disabled veterans in adaptive sports through 2015. It also amends cooperation with organizations managing large-scale adaptive sports programs and extends applicability to Commonwealths and Territories of the United States. The provisions of the new subsection (e) extend applicability to Commonwealths and Territories of the United States for Paralympic sport entities. The reauthorization and modification of the Adaptive Sports Assistance Program include grants for adaptive sports opportunities for disabled veterans and members of the Armed Forces. Eligible entities must have experience in managing large-scale adaptive sports programs. The reauthorization of the Adaptive Sports Assistance Program includes grants for adaptive sports opportunities for disabled veterans and members of the Armed Forces. Eligible entities must have significant experience in managing large-scale adaptive sports programs. Additional application requirements include details on partnerships, costs, financial controls, performance metrics, and expenditures of grant funds. The reauthorization of the Adaptive Sports Assistance Program allows eligible entities to use a portion of the grant for administrative and personnel expenses. The amount for such expenses is limited to 10% for fiscal year 2014, 7.5% for fiscal year 2015, and 5% for subsequent fiscal years. The reauthorization of the Adaptive Sports Assistance Program allows eligible entities to use a portion of the grant for administrative and personnel expenses. The amount for such expenses is limited to 10% for fiscal year 2014, 7.5% for fiscal year 2015, and 5% for subsequent fiscal years. Funding for the program is extended through 2015, with appropriated amounts available without fiscal year limitation. Assistance under the program is authorized for adaptive sports opportunities occurring during fiscal years 2010 through 2016. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress on the use of grants awarded under the Adaptive Sports Assistance Program. The report will assess how the Secretary of Veterans Affairs and eligible entities provided adaptive sports opportunities to veterans, how funds were overseen, and the benefits provided to veterans and members of the Armed Forces through the program. Subsection (f) and (j) are also modified to reflect the adapted sports opportunities funded by the grant. Amendments to Section 521A include consequences for not submitting required reports and clerical changes to the section heading and table of sections. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may implement regulations through interim final rules to ensure grants for adaptive sports programs for disabled veterans and members of the Armed Forces are awarded by the end of fiscal year 2014. Additionally, various authorities and requirements related to transportation, operation of regional offices, and nursing home care for veterans with service-connected disabilities have been extended until December 31, 2014. The extension of various services for veterans with service-connected disabilities, seriously mentally ill and homeless veterans, housing assistance for homeless veterans, advisory committees, and education requirements has been extended until December 31, 2014. The education requirements under Section 3692(c) have been extended until December 31, 2014. Additionally, the authority for medical disabilities examinations by contract physicians has also been extended until the same date.
